title: What songs have the most meaningful lyrics? - Quora

response.answer_text: In recent times, when lyrics like, “then she went and put that booty on that Gucci belt” exist; songs by Troye Sivan have some really meaningful lyrics. The 22-year-old Australian singer writes his own songs along with Alex Hope and a few others. Take any song from his debut EP to his latest track, you'll find some really deep lyrics which are not just enjoyable but also make you ponder over them for a good duration of time. His every song is a quest for those who enjoy finding what the lyrics actually mean. But for me, this one from his third EP, 'Fun' is one of his most lyrically outstanding song. Here it is. Well, don't you want to see the world, boyAll the countries and their stars, boyJust don't look them in the eyes, boyYou just gotta' take their lives, boyLet me take you for a drive, boyOh, I swear you'll feel alive, boy It's quite a general perception that this song is about having fun with your friends. But, no, this song speaks how glorious wars are thought to be. And how young boys are trained to feel patriotic towards their motherland while they kill people particularly in the Middle East. All you gotta' do is trust that I'm being trueAnd do it for the people who love you These lines clearly justify that the young new soldiers are made to trust their leaders that killing a thousand other people just in the name of protecting your own people, your loved ones, isn't a thing to be ashamed of. They are told to let go of all the doubts and do it for their country. Let's go have funYou and me in the old jeepRidin' 'round town with our rifles on the front seatFun, you and me in the Middle EastShootin' at rocks bullets cockedIn the mid-day sun These lines are conflicting. Troye is trying to say that wars are anything besides fun. These lines are a mockery of how countries, particularly, Israel and Palestine are brainwashing young boys into becoming soldiers. Listen to what I tell youYou'll see, my sonNow you know what you gotta doLet's go have fun The word ‘son' itself describes how young and immature the boy is to percept the realities of a war and the harsh consequences of it. The leader is mending his mind to think killing his enemies is a glorious duty for his country. When you're standing on the line, boyDon't go looking for goodbye, boyYeah, you gotta set them free, boy'Cause you know that's what they need, boyYeah, you're gonna make them proud, boy'Til they put you in the ground, boy The recruit is told that no matter how many deaths of fellow soldiers he face, he has to be focused on killing more on the other side. That's the ultimate revenge. Setting the local public free and bringing democracy is helping them towards a better future. He is brainwashed that he's actually helping the people he shoots. He's told that even if he dies, he should be content that all his loved ones will be proud of him for his services. The song was written when Troye was 18. So that pretty much sums it all, I guess.
